ResourceHeader.ResourceName: LANL Daily-averaged electron fluxes from the Synchronous Orbit Particle Spectrometer (SOPA)
ResourceHeader.Description:
Daily-averaged electron fluxes from the Los Alamos
				National Laboratory (LANL) Synchronous Orbit Particle Spectrometer
				(SOPA) Daily averages from each geosynchronous satellite available
				on any given day were merged into a single, uniform daily average.
				Data span 22 September, 1989 through 31 December, 2009. Data are
				log(flux) with flux in units of electrons /(cm^2.s.sr.keV). The
				original SOPA data channels have been fit to a bi-Maxwelian spectra.
				Fluxes are evaluated at virtual "channels" for fixed energies (i.e.
				not for an energy passband or integral thresholds) [see 2010JA015735
				_LANL_Data_and_Processing for details] (2010ja015735-readme.txt)

InformationURL.Name: On the relationship between relativistic electron flux and solar wind velocity: Paulikas and Blake revisited
InformationURL.Description: Describes the processing performed on the SOPA and ESP data that were included in Reeves et. al, 2011

InformationURL.Name: Electronic supplement to "On the relationship between relativistic electron flux and solar wind velocity: Paulikas and Blake Revisited”
InformationURL.Description: Detailed information concerning instruments used, algorithm, and the resulting caveats of usage for data set.

InformationURL.Name: 2010ja015735-readme.txt
InformationURL.Description: Readme file with basic information on processing performed.

AccessURL.Name:
Download link for daily avg. of log LANL-GEO SOPA Avg. Daily
					Flux
AccessURL.Description:
Daily-averaged electron fluxes from the Los Alamos
					National Laboratory (LANL) Synchronous Orbit Particle Spectrometer
					(SOPA) Daily averages from each geosynchronous satellite available
					on any given day were merged into a single, uniform daily average.
					Data span 22 September, 1989 through 31 December, 2009. Data are
					log(flux) with flux in units of electrons /(cm^2.s.sr.keV). The
					original SOPA data channels have been fit to a bi-Maxwelian
					spectra. Fluxes are evaluated at virtual "channels" for fixed
					energies (i.e. not for an energy passband or integral thresholds).

AccessInformation.Acknowledgement:
Reeves, G. D., S. K. Morley, R. H. W. Friedel, M. G.
				Henderson, T. E. Cayton, G. Cunningham, J. B. Blake, R. A.
				Christensen, and D. Thomsen (2011), On the relationship between
				relativistic electron flux and solar wind velocity: Paulikas and
				Blake revisited, J. Geophys. Res., 116, A02213,
				doi:10.1029/2010JA015735.

NumericalData.ProviderResourceName:
Daily-averaged electron fluxes from the Los
			Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) Energetic Spectrometer for
			Particles (ESP)
NumericalData.Caveats:
"Only limited ‘cleaning’ of this data set is performed prior
			to daily averaging and merging. Any detected failures of the fitting
			procedure are first
			removed from the data archive prior to daily averaging. A small fraction of
			daily-averaged flux values appear to be unphysically high. A basic
			‘cleaning’
			is done by excluding any data points at which the evaluated daily
			average
			flux at more than four energies is over four standard deviations above
			the
			mean daily flux for each satellite. We stress that these unphysical
			values
			represent only a small fraction of the data set – many, but not all of these
			values are removed by the basic pre-processing applied here – and
			work is continuing to improve this data set. It should be noted that
			the very highest
			and lowest evaluated energies are extrapolated using the fits and may be
			less
			reliable than those energies within the detection limits of the instrument."
			(Electronic supplement to "On the relationship between relativistic
			electron flux and solar wind velocity: Paulikas and Blake Revisited”)

Parameter.Name: E1 - .0241MeV
Parameter.Description:
Base 10 logarithm of daily-averaged SOPA flux
				measurements selected for each day. Data are for a virtual channel
				at an energy of .0241MeV.
